revision.text:
{{Lead rewrite|date=September 2009}} {{Quote box | quote = By ‘metapolitics’ I mean whatever consequences a philosophy is capable of drawing, both in and for itself, from real instances of politics as thought. Metapolitics is opposed to political philosophy, which claims that since no such politics exists, it falls to philosophers to think ‘the’ political. | | | source = Alain Badiou, April 1998<ref>{{vcite book | author= Badiou, Alain| title= Metapolitics| publisher= London & New York: Verso| date= 2005| isbn= 1-84467- 035-X| pages= xxxix}}</ref> | | width = 35% | align = right }} '''Metapolitics''' (sometimes written meta'''-'''politics) is [[metalinguistic]] talk about the analytic, synthetic, and normative language of political inquiry and politics itself. Put simply, it is dialogue about the way we talk about politics. If one studies, analyzes, and describes a language, the language used for studying, analyzing, and describing the object language is a ''[[metalanguage]]''. In current usage and [[Praxis (process)|praxis]], the term ''metapolitics'' is often used in relation to postmodern theories of the [[Subject (philosophy)#Postmodern subjects|Subject]] and their relation to [[political theory]].<ref>[http://homepages.uwp.edu/zaibert/inprogress/Zaibert%20Final%20Versions/Zaibert%20Toward%20Meta-Politics.pdf Toward Meta-Politics]</ref> In its broadest definition, ''metapolitics'' is a discipline that studies the relationship between the State and the Individual.<ref>Other "meta-" discourses: Since ''Metapolitics'' in its current usage takes on [[inter-disciplinary]] characteristics, it is often discussed in relation to other disciplines, including mathematics (science) and art. When mathematicians are concerned with utilizing the formula, signs, and language of mathematics in order to talk about the formal system itself they are engaging in a metalanguage. To discuss the system of axioms which constitutes the foundation of mathematical talk (ie., [[calculus]] or [[set theory]]), mathematicians (or any lay person) would occupy themselves with ''metamathematics'' (talk about mathematical talk). Those who occupy themselves with the examination, analysis, and description of the language of science, occupy themselves with ''metascience''.</ref>
==See also== *[[Alain Badiou]] *[[Sylvain Lazarus]] *[[Jason Barker]]
==References== <references/>
*Carlo Gambescia, ''Metapolitica. L’altro sguardo sul potere'', Edizioni Il Foglio Letterario 2009, pp. 105 - ISBN 978 88 7606 247 6
==External links== *A. J. Gregor. Metascience and Politics. [http://www.tiscali.co.uk/reference/dictionaries/difficultwords/data/d0008232.html Dictionary definition] *Peter Viereck, ''[http://books.google.gr/books?id=xJS44lXfKvYC&pg=PA134&lpg=PA134&dq=metapolitics&source=bl&ots=wQs-q_zSM_&sig=f1wEq40TSRdOk7J7KvcFIjci4FI&hl=el&ei=SfsLStDTDMSv_AbGhsSgBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9 Metapolitics: From Wagner and the German Romantics to Hitler]'', 2003. ISBN 978-0-7658-0510-2. *[http://www.nhinet.org/viereck16-2.pdf Peter Viereck, Metapolitics Revisited] *[http://www.versobooks.com/books/ab/b-titles/badiou_a_metapolitics.shtml Commentary on Alain Badiou's book ''Metapolitics''] *[http://mises.org/journals/qjae/pdf/qjae7_4_8.pdf Leo Zaibert, ''Toward Meta-politics'']
